oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Interactions between sympatric invasive European fire ants (Myrmica rubra) and blacklegged ticks (Ixodes scapularis)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Guarnieri, Lucy D
McBride, Sara E
Groden, Eleanor
Gardner, Allison M
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ixodes scapularis
invasive species
Myrmica rubra
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>The blacklegged tick (<jats:italic>Ixodes scapularis</jats:italic>) and the invasive European fire ant (<jats:italic>Myrmica rubra</jats:italic>) are both expanding throughout their sympatric range in coastal New England. <jats:italic>Ixodes scapularis</jats:italic> is the primary vector of the bacterium <jats:italic>Borrelia burgdorferi</jats:italic>, which is the causative agent of Lyme disease, and Mount Desert Island, Maine, home to Acadia National Park, currently is affected by a high Lyme disease burden. Ticks have many natural predators, including ants, although no previous studies have investigated interactions between these two species. To test the hypothesis that the presence of <jats:italic>M</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>rubra</jats:italic> alters <jats:italic>I</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>scapularis</jats:italic> abundance, we collected ticks by drag-sampling at eight ant-infested sites and eight uninfested control sites in Acadia National Park. We found that nymph density was significantly higher at ant-infested sites, while larval density was significantly higher at control sites. In addition, we conducted a laboratory bioassay to measure <jats:italic>M</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>rubra</jats:italic> aggression against <jats:italic>I</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>scapularis</jats:italic> larvae, nymphs, and adults and <jats:italic>Dermacentor variabilis</jats:italic> adults, and found that ant aggression was significantly higher against <jats:italic>D</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>variabilis</jats:italic> adults than <jats:italic>I</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>scapularis</jats:italic> adults. Our findings support the hypothesis that <jats:italic>M</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>rubra</jats:italic> has divergent effects across <jats:italic>I</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>scapularis</jats:italic> life stages, and we discuss possible ecological mechanisms, including optimal microclimate and predation, that could promote density of nymphs while inhibiting density of larvae.</jats:p>
